title: ICE with `match` statement on a struct with `const fn` constructor

labels.name: A-const-fn
labels.description: Area: const fn foo(..) {..}. Pure functions which can be applied at compile time.

body:
Consider a simple `struct` which can be created at compile time (used in `const`s):
```rust
#[derive(Eq, PartialEq)]
struct A { value: u32 }

const fn new(value: u32) -> A {
  A { value }
}
```

I then defined some named constants:
```rust
const A_1: A = new(1);
const A_2: A = new(2);
```

Later on, I tried to use `match` to convert a variable of type `A` to a string:
```rust
let a_str = match a {
   A_1 => "A 1",
   A_2 => "A 2",
   _ => "Unknown A",
};
```

This leads to the following compiler crash:
```
error: internal compiler error: /checkout/src/librustc_const_eval/_match.rs:261: bad constructor ConstantValue(Const { ty: A, val: Aggregate(Struct([(value(91), Const { ty: u32, val: Integral(U32(1)) })])) }) for adt A

note: the compiler unexpectedly panicked. this is a bug.

note: we would appreciate a bug report: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#bug-reports

note: rustc 1.23.0-nightly (5041b3bb3 2017-11-19) running on x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu

thread 'rustc' panicked at 'Box<Any>', /checkout/src/librustc_errors/lib.rs:471:8
note: Run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` for a backtrace.
```

Also [uploaded](https://play.rust-lang.org/?gist=fe1b91ecb18358fe5a72300d7033ba30&version=nightly) the sample code to the Rust Playground.

As a side-note: it does not crash if I manually construct the structs, i.e.
```rust
const A_1: A = A { value: 1 };
const A_2: A = A { value: 2 };
```

Alternatively, it also works if I replace the `match` with if / else chains.
